results.title: Monsieur Vincent
results.brief_description:
The life and work of Saint Vincent de Paul, who was in conflict with the rich and powerful because of his pioneer work among the poor. Although the film had some financial backing from the catholic Church, this inspiring depiction of saintliness contains only a modicum of sermonizing. The beauty of the photography does not exclude the strakness of the poverty or the brutality of the age. Fresnay, growing from a young man to old age, carries even atheists along with him. Awards: Academy Awards (Oscars) 1948: Best foreign film ; Venice Film Festival (Mostra) 1948: Best actor for Pierre Fresnay. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Director, Maurice Cloche ; writers, Jean Bernard-Luc, Jean Anouihl ; photography, Claude Renoir ; music, J. Grunenwald.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Aime Clariond, Pierre Dux, Jean Debucourt, Lise Delamare, Gabrielle Dorziat.

results.title: La Cousine Bette
results.brief_description:
Cousine Bette is fast approaching 40 and hoping to marry a young man, Wenceslas, 20 years her senior, whose studies she is supporting financially. Upon learning that her trust and hopes have been betrayed and that Wenceslas is about to marry Hortense, Bette’s young niece, the ‘poor cousin’ sets up a plot to destroy her entire family by exploiting their weaknesses.

Credits: Director, Yves-Andre Hubert ; writers, Jean-Louis Bory ‘ photography, Rene Mathelin ; music, Dominique Paladilhe.
Cast: Alice Sapritch, Daniele Lebrun, Jean Sobieski, Elina Labourdette, Jacques Castelot, Claudine Coster, Jacques Monod.

results.title: L'homme Au Chapeau Rond
results.brief_description:
When his wife Nathalie dies, Nicolas, a former judge, hits the bottle. His mood becomes even grimmer when he learns that his daughter Lisa is in fact the result of Nathalie’s affair with Michel. One night, Nicolas approaches Michel with his revelations and Michel promises to look after the child. But soon after the child is despatched to the country and the two men resume their favorite game: womanising.

Credits: Director, Pierre Billon ; writers, Charles Spaak, Pierre Brive ; photography, Nicolas Toporkoff ; music, Maurice Thiriet ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Raimu, Aime Clariond, Lucy Valnor, Gisele Casadessus, Louis Seigner, Jane Marken, Micheline Boudet, France Delahalle.

results.title: Le Voyage En Ballon = Stowaway in the Sky
results.brief_description:
A small child, fascinated by a lighter-than-air balloon, clambers aboard. The balloon takes flight, lifting the child upward to an amazing adventure.

Credits: Producer, Jean Velter ; director, Albert Lamorisse ; writer, Albert Lamorisse ; photography, Maurice Fellous ; music, Jean Podromides.
Cast: Pascal Lamorisse, Andre Gille, Maurice Baquet.

results.title: A double tour = Web of passion
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
Henri is married to Therese and together they have two children. Henri also has a mistress, Leda. The adulterous relationship is known to all around him, but all feign to ignore it. One day, Therese breaks the silence and confronts Henri about Leda. Not long after, Leda is found dead. ‘A double tour’, Chabrol’s first colour film, is especially notable for its striking cinematography, its complex narrative structure, and the exuberance of its flamboyant style; it represents Chabrol’s first studied attempt to examine and criticize the moral values of the bourgeoisie as well as to dissect the sociopsychological causes of the violence which inevitably erupts as the social and family structures prove inadequate.” Reference: Charles Derry. ‘Claude Chabrol’. Online. Available: http://www.geocities.com/Paris/Metro/9384/directors/chabrol/derry.htm ; Originally published: ‘International Dictionary of Films and Filmmakers, Vol. 2: Directors, 3rd ed. (Detroit: St. James Press, 1997), p. 148, 150-151.

Credits: Producer, Robert and Raymond Hakim ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writers, Paul Gegauff, Claude Chabrol ; photography, Henri Decae ; music, Paul Misraki ; art direction, Jacques Saulnier, Bernard Evein ; director’s assistant, Philippe De Broca
Cast: Jacques Dacqmine, Antonella Lualdi, Andre Jocelyn, Jeanne Valerie, Bernadette Lafont, Madeleine Robinson, Jean-Paul Belmondo.

results.title: Les Bonnes Femmes = the Good Girls
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
Four shop girls long to escape the monotony of their existence: Ginette sings in a tatty music-hall; Rita drifts into a bourgeois marriage; Jane simply wants a good time; Jacqueline yearns for romantic love but is strangled by a maniac. Chabrol’s early masterpiece offers a gallery of grotesques, macabre and farcical humour, but also poetry and tenderness. The mixture of compassion for the girls and contempt for their dreams created an ironic structure that disturbed the majority of critics when it first appeared.

Credits: Producer, Robert and Raymond Hakim ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writers, Claude Chabrol, Paul Gegauff ; photography, Henri Decae ; music, Paul Misraki, Pierre Jansen.
Cast: Bernadette Lafont, Stephane Audran, Clotilde Joano, Lucile Saint-Simon, Ave Ninchi, Mario David, Sacha Briquet, Claude Berri.

results.title: Pickpocket
results.creator_credit: Robert Bresson, Agnes Delahaie and Agnes Delahaie Productions
results.brief_description:
“Bresson’s masterpiece was voted the greatest postwar French film by ‘Cahiers du cinema’, which somehow doesn’t do it justice. As Rene Predal has argued, it is one of four films, along with Resnais’ ‘Hiroshima mon amour’, Antonioni’s ‘L’avventura’, and Godard’s ‘A Bout de Souffle’, that ‘constitute the quartet of germinal films of the modern cinema’. ‘Pickpocket’ has exercised an enormous influence on directors as disparate as Fassbinder, Akerman, Scorsese, Aki Kaurismaki, Malle (who called it ‘one of four or five great dates in the history of cinema’), and Schrader (who pronounced it ‘an unmitigated masterpiece’ and lifted its ending for the denouement of his own ‘American Gigolo’). Loosely based on Dostoevsky’s ‘Crime and Punishment’, Bresson’s intense portrait of a compulsive pickpocket who believes himself above the moral constraints of common humanity turns the mechanics of theft into a ritual both erotically and spiritually charged. The ‘ballets of thievery’, as Cocteau called them, are among the most beautifully choreographed and edited sequences in cinema. ‘A film of dazzling originality. On its first viewing, it risks burning your eyes. So, do like me: Go back to see it again every day … If you deny this film, it is cinema itself as an autonomous art that you call into question’ (Louis Malle).” Reference: James Quandt. The poetry of precision: the films of Robert Bresson. Cinematheque Ontario. Online. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/bresson.htm. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Agnes Delahaie ; director, Robert Bresson ; writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Leonce-Henri Burel ; music, Jean-Baptiste Lulli ; editing, Raymond Lamy.
Cast: Martin Lasalle, Marika Green, Pierre Leymarie, Pierre Etaix.

results.title: Le Roi et L'oiseau = the King and the Mockingbird
results.brief_description:
A despotic king kidnaps a shepherdess with whom he is in love. He forces her to marry him in return for the freedom of her true love, a chimneysweep, and his mockingbird. When they escape from prison, the king attempts to recapture them with the help of a giant robot. A first version of ‘Le roi et l’oiseau’ was released in 1952 as ‘La bergere et le ramoneur’ (The shepherdess and the Chimneysweep). Grimault and Prevert disowned this version which had been imposed to them by the producers. Ten years later, Grimault retrieved the negative and started work on a new version. Prevert died in 1970, 2 weeks after completing the film. The film was again modified between 1977 and 1979 (although many original sections were kept) to be released in France in 1980. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1979.

Credits: Producer, Paul Grimault ; director, Paul Grimault ; writers, Paul Grimault, Jacques Prevert ; photography, Gerard Soirant ; music, Wojcieh Kilar ; songwriter, Joseph Kosma ; set decorator, editor, Paul Grimault ; artistic advisor, Pierre Prev
Cast: Jean Martin, Pascal Mazzotti, Agnes Viala, Raymond Bussieres, Hubert Deschamps, Roger Blin, Claude Pieplu, Albert Medina. [voices only]

results.title: Paulina 1880
results.creator_credit: Jean-Louis Bertucelli and Albina du Boisrouvray
results.brief_description:
Paulina is the only daughter of an upper class family in 19th century Italy. She grows up under the preying eyes of her large and domineering family and can only dream about love. Between her dreams and her religious devotion, she finds time to fall in love with a married nobleman. Sensing the untenability of the situation, Paulina considers entering a convent, but not before she has a last encounter with her lover.

Credits: Producer, Albina du Boisrouvray ; director, Jean-Louis Bertucelli ; writers, Albina du Boisrouvray, Jean-Louis Bertucelli ; photography, Andreas Winding ; music, Nicolas Nabokov.
Cast: Olga Karlatos, Maximilian Schell, Eliana de Santis, Michel Bouquet, Sami Frey.

results.title: Le Portrait de Marianne = the Picture of Marianne
results.brief_description:
Octave has just been ‘dumped’ by his wife, Marianne. Together with his good friend Alfred, they go looking for her across Paris. As their conversation unfolds, they attempts to make sense of their relationships with women.

Credits: Producer, Eric Geiger ; director, Daniel Goldenberg ; writers, Daniel Goldenberg, Edgar de Bresson ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Philippe Carson.
Cast: Claude Brasseur, Karen Blanguernon, Bernard Fresson, Liliane Rovere, Jacques Rispal.
